titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Michael C. Heenan collection 1973.256
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:14:22 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection consists of a diary of Michael C. Heenan of Brooklyn, containing notations on his appointments as Messenger and Assistant Sergeant-at-Arms of the Kings County Board of Supervisors, as well as clippings on activities of Brooklyn 10th Ward Democratic organizations in which Heenan was active. Also included are two U.S. Naval cloth insignias of the rank of Sergeant, circa 1945; two black-and-white photographs of a young boy (presumed to be Heenan) with a pony; and an account book, checkbooks, and a Labor Bureau notice belonging to Kathryn and Thomas McGee, whose relation to Heenan is not known.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Michael C. Heenan collection, 1973.256, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Michael C. Heenan was Messenger and Assistant Sergeant-at-Arms for the Kings County Board of Supervisors, and was also active in the Democratic party in Brooklyn's 10th Ward.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of a diary of Michael C. Heenan of Brooklyn, containing notations on his appointments as Messenger and Assistant Sergeant-at-Arms of the Kings County Board of Supervisors, as well as clippings on activities of Brooklyn 10th Ward Democratic organizations in which Heenan was active. Also included are two U.S. Naval cloth insignias of the rank of Sergeant, circa 1945; two black-and-white photographs of a young boy (presumed to be Heenan) with a pony; and an account book, checkbooks, and a Labor Bureau notice belonging to Kathryn and Thomas McGee, whose relation to Heenan is not known.
